# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is a Julia function that meets the task requirements:

```julia
function wrap_string(s, text_width::Int=10) 
    words = split(s, " ")  
    result = String[]
    line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(line * " " * word) > text_width
            push!(result, line)
            line = word
        else
            line = line * " " * word
        end
    end 
    push!(result, line)
    return join(result, "\n")
end 
```
You can call the function like this:

```julia
println(wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines", text_width=10))
```

This code works by splitting the input string into words, then checking each word to see if it would cause the line length to exceed `text_width` when added. If it does, we append the current line to our result array and start a new line with just that word. If it won't, we add the word to the current line. After processing all words, we always add the remaining line to our results array before returning. The join operation at the end is used to convert the Array of strings into one string where each line is separated by a newline character.
